newsitem.title: USA: CSX train derails in Washington, no injuries.
newsitem.headline: CSX train derails in Washington, no injuries.

text.p: Ten cars of a CSX Transportation. freight train derailed near Washington and sideswiped an Amtrak passenger train around 6 p.m. EDT on Tuesday, but no injuries were reported, officials from both companies said.
The accident occurred in Virginia, just south of Washington's 14th St. railroad bridge, between the Potomac River and the George Washington Parkway.
The derailment involved the final 10 cars of a 57-car CSX train traveling northbound from Jacksonville, Florida to Philadelphia, hauled by three locomotives, CSX spokeswoman Kathy Burns said.
She said the cause of the accident had not yet been determined, but the company would conduct a full investigation.
Burns said neither the crew of the CSX train, nor passengers aboard the Amtrak train reported any injuries.
As the 10 CSX cars came off the track, they sideswiped a southbound Amtrak passenger train heading from Boston to Richmond, Amtrak spokeswoman Maureen Garrity told Reuters.
Garrity said the six-car Amtrak train separated between the fourth and fifth cars, and officials were still trying to recouple the train and move it from the site.
Passengers on Amtrak Train # 93 were still aboard, Garrity said.
CSX Transportation is a unit of CSX Corp. The CSX train included tractor trailers and containers on flat railcars, Burns said.
"We will undergo an extensive investigation," Burns said. "Our goal is to determine what did cause it and ensure it does not happen again."

CSX was determined to maintain its three-year record as the safest railroad in the United States, Burns said, noting the railroad reported 1.91 accidents per million train miles, the lowest ratio of all U.S. railroads.
Garrity said Amtrak expected delays, but had no details at this point.
